author: vorot93
content: Probably need to add a no-difficulty-bomb chainspec to akula, just to make a point about difficulty bomb uselessness

author: vorot93
content: (actually, OE can do this too, with bomb delays being a field in parity chainspec json)

author: ajsutton
content: The difficulty has never been the code change, it's the coordination.  Even if the chainspec already exists you still have to coordinate to get people to swap over to it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is also value in proving you have a distribution mechanism.  By explicitly *not* including a built-in no-bomb feature, it ensures that whoever tries to fork has the ability to release code and get people to coordinate on that released code.

author: sky.cactus
content: If all clients came with a no-bomb config, then someone wanting to fork wouldn't need to actually have a distribution mechanism for security fixes and such.

author: yperbasis
content: "Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb"

author: _shemnon
content: A no-bomb config isn't enough, you would need to coordinate a block to stop applying the bomb difficulty adjustments, the difference is it's almost always not noticeable outside of block validation until it approaches hundreds of milliseconds of impact, then suddenly it's seconds.  (meme: The Difficulty Bomb is going off?  Always has been.)
